page.title: 06Mines Rescue Station
page.content: Boothstown Mines Rescue Station was one of the first stations built. It is the most modern of its kind in Europe. It was built in 1932. Most stations were converted buildings, but Boothstown was specially made. The Mines Rescue workers job is to rescue people when there is a lack of fresh air. They take a medical kit and amputation kit down with them. Luckily the amputation kit has never been used. Their main aim is to rescue all survivors. Next they put out all the fires and then ventilate the pit. Lastly they get out the dead bodies. At all times even on bank holidays, Christmas and Boxing Day, there is a team of 6 men and at least 1 official on duty. There is a bell in each house in Orchard Avenue, the street down the side of the station where the workers live which rings in an emergency.
